Home Iwi and communities Translations Te reo Māori Te haere ki, i Aotearoa | Travel to and from New Zealand Whakamātautau i mua i te wehe mō te hunga haere ki Aotearoa | Pre-departure testing for travellers to New Zealand --- Section Separator --- Ka noho tonu ko te kauparenga nui mō tātou ko te ārai atu i te huaketo mai i Aotearoa. E whakaritea ana kia whiwhi te nuinga o ngā kaihāereere ki Aotearoa i tētahi whakamātautau KOWHEORI-19 i mua i te wehe e kī ana kāore rātou i te mate mai i tētahi whare pūtaiao whaimana, i roto i te 72 hāora i mua i tō rātou wehenga tuatahi ki tāwāhi. Ka wātea ngā whenua e whai ake nei i tētahi whakamātau i mua i te wehenga: Te Tiri o te Moana (Antarctica) Kuki Airani (The Cook Islands) Ngā Whenua Tōpū o Maikoronihia (Federated States of Micronesia) Whītī (Fiji) Kiripati Ngā Moutere o Marshall Nauru Kanaki (New Caledonia) Niue Pārao Hāmoa (Samoa) Ngā Motu o Horomona (Solomon Islands) Tokerau Tonga Tūwaru Whenuatū Kua whakaūngia e te Manatu Hauora ngā momo whakamātautau e whai ake nei e whakaaetia ana mō ngā whenua katoa hāunga ngā whenua o Ahitereiria me ngā whenua tino mōrearea: Whakamātau Whakarahi Waikawa Karihi (NAAT), kei roto ko te PCR, RT-PCR me te TMA, LAMP, whakamātau ā-paturopi (tērā pea e kīia ana he whakamātau wheori paturopi) rānei. E whakaritea ana kia whiwhi ngā kaihāereere mai i Ahitereiria i ngā whakamātautau PCR, RT-PCR rānei i mua i te wehenga. Me whai taunakitanga rawa ngā kaihāereere mai i ngā whenua tino mōrearea o tētahi whakamātautau ihu-korokoro RT-PCR (PCR) e kī ana kāore rātou i te mate mai i tētahi whare pūtaiao whaimana. Kimihia ētahi atu kōrero mō ngā whenua tino mōrearea Ka wātea ngā tamariki i raro iho i te rua tau (24 marama) i ngā whakamātautau i mua i te wehenga. Ka wātea ngā kaihāereere e whakawhiti ana mā Aotearoa ki tō rātou taunga whakamutunga, me te noho i te taha rerenga, i ngā whakamātautau i mua i te wehenga. Ko ngā kaihāereere kāore e āhei atu te whai whakamātautau nā ngā take rongoā, me toro atu ki tētahi tākuta i roto i te 72 hāora i mua i tō rātou wehenga. Me tuku rātou i tētahi tiwhikete rongoā ki a koe e kī ana e kore koe e āhei ki te whai tētahi whakamātautau nā ngā take rongoā, ā, kāore i a koe ngā tohumate o te KOWHEORI-19. Mēnā he whakamātautau tāu i mua i te wehenga e kī ana kua whai tohumate koe, engari e whakapono ana koe nā tētahi whakapokenga o mua o te KOWHEORI-19, me toro atu koe ki tētahi tākuta māna koe e tirotiro mō ngā tohumate hou o te KOWHEORI-19. Mēnā e tino mōhio ana ia kāore i a koe tētahi pokenga KOWHEORI-19 i taua wā tonu, māna e tuku ki a koe: tētahi tiwhikete rongoā me te rā o tō whakamātautau o mua e kī ana kei te mate, ā, mēnā e hāngai ana, ngā tuhinga e whāki ana, e whakaaro ana ia kua kore koe e pokea e te KOWHEORI-19. E whakaaetia ana ngā tiwhikete rongoā i roto i ngā reo kē. E tino tohutohua ana te hunga haere ki te pātai ki tō(ō) rātau kamupene rererangi mō ētahi atu whakaritenga whakamātau i mua i te wehenga. E tohutohua ana hoki rātau kia tirotirohia nga whakaritenga o ētahi atu whenua ka whakawhitia e rātau. Kia tae ki Aotearoa, e hiahiatia ana te nuinga o te hunga haere, hāunga ērā e haere mai ana hei wāhi ote Haerenga Taratahi Kore , kia: Noho mō te 14 rā i roto i tā mātau tukanga noho mohoao, taratahi hoki whiwhi i tētahi whakamātau PCR KOWHEORI-19 i te rā 0, arā, i tō rātau taenga ki te wāhi noho mohoao mō te wā tuatahi noho ki roto i tō rātou rūma kia tutuki rā anō te putanga o taua whakamātautau mēnā he tohumate ō rātou i te taetanga atu, ka kawea tikahia ki tētahi whare noho taratahi. Ko te tikanga ka 24-48 hāora te roa i mua i te whiwhinga i ngā hua whakamātautau. Mēnā ka kī te whakamātautau kāore te tangata i te mate, ka tutuki i a ia te toenga o te 14 rā i roto i te wāhi noho mohoao. Ka whakaritea kia whakamātautauria anō rātou i te rā 3 pea o te noho, ā, me te rā 12. I te nuinga o ngā kēhi, e hiahiatia ana tētahi whakamātautau KOWHEORI-19 e kī ana kāore te tangata i te mate me te whakaūtanga mai i tā mātou rōpū hauora he iti te mōrearea kua pāngia, o te horapa rānei i te KOWHEORI-19, i mua i te wehenga i te whare noho. Mēnā e ai ki te otinga kei te pāngia te tangata, ka whakawhitia taua tangata ki te whare noho taratahi i mua noa atu mēnā kāore he whakamātautau rā 0. Rapua ētahi atu kōrero mō te Haere Taratahi Kore Mō ngā whakahounga hou rawa o te KOWHEORI-19, tēnā toro atu ki https://covid19.govt.nz/updates-and-resources/translations/ Mō ētahi atu mōhiohio mō te noho mohoao me te noho taratahi tēnā toro atu ki: https://www.miq.govt.nz/travel-to-new-zealand/arriving-in-nz/ (external link) --- Section Separator --- Ka noho tonu ko te kauparenga nui mō tātou ko te ārai atu i te huaketo mai i Aotearoa. I te nuinga o ngā kēhi, e hiahiatia ana tētahi whakamātautau KOWHEORI-19 e kī ana kāore te tangata i te mate me te whakaūtanga mai i tā mātou rōpū hauora he iti te mōrearea kua pāngia, o te horapa rānei i te KOWHEORI-19, i mua i te wehenga i te whare noho. Mēnā e ai ki te otinga kei te pāngia te tangata, ka whakawhitia taua tangata ki te whare noho taratahi i mua noa atu mēnā kāore he whakamātautau rā 0. Rapua ētahi atu kōrero mō te Haere Taratahi Kore Mō ngā whakahounga hou rawa o te KOWHEORI-19, tēnā toro atu ki https://covid19.govt.nz/updates-and-resources/translations/ Mō ētahi atu mōhiohio mō te noho mohoao me te noho taratahi tēnā toro atu ki: https://www.miq.govt.nz/travel-to-new-zealand/arriving-in-nz/ (external link) --- Section Separator --- Information for Māori Support and information for Pacific Peoples Support and information for disabled people Support your community Alternate formats Translations አማርኛ | Amharic عربي | Arabic Bislama 简体中文 | Chinese (Simplified) 繁體中文 | Chinese (Traditional) Te Reo Māori Kuki ‘Āirani | Cook Islands Māori Español | Spanish دری | Dari فارسی | Farsi Vosa Vakaviti | Fijian ગુજરાતી | Gujarati हिन्दी / Hindi 日本語 | Japanese ကညီ | Karen Te taetae ni Kiribati | Kiribati 한국어 | Korean Bahasa Malaysia | Malay Vagahau Niue | Niuean پښتو | Pashto ਪੰਜਾਬੀ / Punjabi Rohingya Fäeag Rotuḁm | Rotuman Gagana Samoa | Samoan Solomon Aelan Pijin | Solomon Islands Pijin Af-Soomaali | Somali Kiswahili | Swahili Tagalog Te reo Māori தமிழ் | Tamil ภาษาไทย | Thai ትግርኛ | Tigrinya Tok Pisin Te Gagana Tokelau | Tokelauan Lea Faka Tonga | Tongan Te Gana Tuvalu | Tuvaluan اُردُو | Urdu Tiếng Việt | Vietnamese አማርኛ | Amharic عربي | Arabic Bislama 简体中文 | Chinese (Simplified) 繁體中文 | Chinese (Traditional) Te Reo Māori Kuki ‘Āirani | Cook Islands Māori Español | Spanish دری | Dari فارسی | Farsi Vosa Vakaviti | Fijian ગુજરાતી | Gujarati हिन्दी / Hindi 日本語 | Japanese ကညီ | Karen Te taetae ni Kiribati | Kiribati 한국어 | Korean Bahasa Malaysia | Malay Vagahau Niue | Niuean پښتو | Pashto ਪੰਜਾਬੀ / Punjabi Rohingya Fäeag Rotuḁm | Rotuman Gagana Samoa | Samoan Solomon Aelan Pijin | Solomon Islands Pijin Af-Soomaali | Somali Kiswahili | Swahili Tagalog Te reo Māori தமிழ் | Tamil ภาษาไทย | Thai ትግርኛ | Tigrinya Tok Pisin Te Gagana Tokelau | Tokelauan Lea Faka Tonga | Tongan Te Gana Tuvalu | Tuvaluan اُردُو | Urdu Tiếng Việt | Vietnamese
Home Iwi and communities Translations Te reo Māori Te haere ki, i Aotearoa | Travel to and from New Zealand Te Haere Taratahi-Kore | Quarantine-Free Travel --- Section Separator --- Puka Hāereere Taratahi Kore: Ahitereiria (Australia) → Aotearoa kua whakatārewatia (Suspended) He 7-rā te wā e wātea ana mō ‘ngā rerenga hoki kākāriki’ mai i ngā rohe takiwā katoa o Ahitereiria (hāunga a NSW) kia hoki ai te hunga haere ki te kāinga. Kāore te hunga hoki i runga i ēnei rerenga e mate ki te noho taratahi i te hokinga atu, engari anō mēnā kei te haere atu koe mai i Victoria . Tēnā hihiratia auautia te whārangi Hāereere Taratahi-Kore kei te paetukutuku o Unite Against COVID-19 mō ngā mōhiohio hou rawa. Ki te raru ō whakaritenga hāereere, ka taea e koe te whakapā atu ki tō pakihi rererangi, kaiwhakarite hāereere me te kaiinihua hāereere. I tēnei wā, he ritenga Taratahi-Kore tō Aotearoa me ēnei motu: Ahitereiria Kūki Airani Niue (mai i Niue ki Aotearoa anake) Ko te tikanga o te Haere Taratahi-Kore, ko te neke mai i tētahi motu ki tētahi me te kore noho taratahi inā ka tae atu koe. Kāore hoki he take o te whakamātautau i mua i tāu wehenga. Ka taea e te tangata te Haere Taratahi-Kore noa inā tatū ngā paearu ritenga, me ngā ritenga take manene o te motu e haere nā koe. I tēnei wā, ko ngā Haere Taratahi-Kore, ko te haere i waenganui o Aotearoa me tētahi atu motu anake. Hei tauira, ka āhei koe ki te Haere Taratahi-Kore i waenganui o Kūki Airani me Aotearoa, engari me noho taratahi rawa koe mō te 14 rā i mua i te haerenga ki te whenua Taratahi-Kore o Ahitereiria. Māna kei te noho kape koe, me mau ārai kanohi, uhi kanohi rānei inā haere mai ana koe ki Aotearoa, inā wehe atu ana rānei. Me mau ārai kanohi hoki koe i runga i ngā waka tūmatanui katoa o Aotearoa. Ko ētahi anō tāngata kāore he take ki te mau ārai kanohi. Ki te panoni Te Pae Mataara ki Aotearoa, ki te rerekē rānei te āhuatanga ki tētahi motu Haere Taratahi-Kore, ka pāhongia e tēnei pae tukutuku ( covid19.govt.nz ), me ngā pae tukutuku rongo kōrero. Ki te puta anō te mate ki te hapori i Aotearoa nei, i tētahi motu Taratahi-Kore rānei, tērā ka whakatūria e te Kāwanatanga te haere taratahi-kore hei aromātai i te tūraru, tērā rānei hīkina ngā haerenga mō tētahi wā roa ake. Me whai mahere te hunga haere, me rite hoki mō te tūpono raru rānei i ōu haerenga. Tirohia mai ngā whakamārama hou rawa mō Te Haere Taratahi-Kore E āhei ai koe ki te haere taratahi-kore ki Aotearoa: me tutuki ngā here manene katoa me whiwhi i tētahi whakamātautau wehe tōmua tōraro i roto i te 72 hāora i mua i te wehenga mēnā e haere mai ana koe i Ahitereiria. me noho rawa koe ki Aotearoa, ki te motu rānei e haere nā koe mō te 14 rā. Hei tauira, mēnā e wehe ana koe i Ahitereiria, me mātua noho koe ki Ahitereiria, ki Aotearoa rānei mō te 14 rā e wātea ai ki te haere taratahi-kore. Ka wātea koe ki te haere atu i te 15 o ngā rā mēnā kāore koe i raru i te whakamātautau KOWHEORI-19 i roto i te 14 rā i mua i tō wehenga. Mēnā kua pāngia kē koe, me mātua whiwhi tuhi whakaaetanga koe i tētahi kaimahi hauora, e kī ana kua makere katoa atu te mate i a koe mēnā kāore koe i te tiaki kia hoki mai he whakamātautau KOWHEORI-19 me whakakī rawa he tauākī haerenga (external link) – mēnā kāore e whakakīa kāore koe e whakaaetia kia kake i te waka rererangi me whakautu rawa he pātai e pā ana ki tō hauora hei te wehenga atu. Mēnā he mate tōu e taunaki ana i ōu tohumate, me kawe mai e koe tētahi tiwhikete hauora kia kore ai koe e aukatia ki te kake i te waka rererangi. Rapua ētahi atu kōrero mō ngā whakamātautau wehe tōmua Tāutangia, whakamahia hoki te taupānga Kaiaru KOWHEORI o Aotearoa. Kāore he raru nō Aotearoa rānei tō waea pūkoro, tō kaute Āporo, tō kaute Kūkara rānei, mō te tāuta i te Kaiaru KOWHEORI. Tāutangia te Taupānga Kaiaru KOWHEORI o Aotearoa ki te Pātaka Taupānga (external link) Tāutangia te Taupānga Kaiaru KOWHEORI o Aotearoa ki Kūkara Purei (external link) Mēnā kei a koe ngā tohumate o te hūwiniwini, o te rewharewha o te KOWHEORI-19 rānei, me noho ki te kāinga ka waea atu ki: te waea-hauora Healthline i te nama kore-utu 0800 358 5453 tō rata, rānei tō kaiwhakarato hauora ā-iwi rānei. Mā te mātanga hauora e tohu atu mēnā me whakamātautau koe. Tēnā waea atu ki tō rata i mua i tō haerenga atu mēnā he tohumate ōu. E haere taratahi-kore koe ki Ahitereiria: me tatū ngā ritenga manene me noho rawa koe ki Aotearoa, ki Ahitereiria rānei mō te 14 rā i mua i tō wehenga – arā ka āhei koe ki te haere atu i te 15 o ngā rā. me whakakī rawa he tauākī haere kia 72 hāora rawa i mua i te wehenga atu i Aotearoa ( https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/australia-traveldeclaration (external link) ) mēnā kāore ōu tohumate KOWHEORI-19 mēnā kāore koe i pāngia e tētahi tangata mate KOWHEORI-19 me tiro rawa kei te whakaae te rohe te takiwā rānei e haere ana koe, ki ngā rererangi Taratahi-Kore. I a koe i Ahitereiria, he ruarua ngā mea kia mahara iho koe e haumaru ake ai koutou ko tō whānau, ko te hapori hoki, i te KOWHEORI-19, pērā i te noho akuaku me te tuhi i ō wāhi taenga atu. Mō ngā whakamārama mõ te KOWHEORI-19, mō ngā wāhi aronui, mō ngā tūāhua haerenga (tae atu ki ngā haerenga o te motu) me ngā whakamātautau, haere koa ki te pae tukutuku o te rohe kei reira koe. E whai ake nei ko ngā pārongo KOWHEORI-19 mō ia rohe, mō ia takiwā rānei: Te Takiwā Matua o Ahitereiria (external link) Niu Taute Wēra (external link) Te Takiwā o te Raki (external link) Kuīniwhenua (external link) Ahitereiria ki te Tonga (external link) Tāhimana (external link) Wikitōria (external link) Ahitereiria ki te Uru (external link) Arā tonu tētahi taupānga aru mō Ahitereiria whānui, engari he taupānga kē tō te nuinga o ia rohe o ia takiwā. Ka taea e koe te tāuta i te nuinga o ēnei taupānga me te kāri SIM o Aotearoa. Me whai pea koe i tētahi kāri SIM o Ahitereiria, i ngā taipitopito whakapā o Ahitereiria rānei, hei whakamahi i ētahi o ēnei taupānga. Ko tā mātou ki a koutou, me puri ēnei taupānga ki tō waea mō te 1 marama, mō te tūpono whiwhi whakatūpatotanga koe whai muri i tō wehenga atu i te rohe. Ki te kore e taea, e pīrangitia rānei te whakamahi i te taupānga, me whakamahi rawa e koe ngā taupānga a ngā pakihi ake me ngā toa ake, i mua i tō takiurutanga. Tāutangia ngā taupānga ā-rohe: Te Takiwā Matua o Ahitereiria (ACT) – Tirohia te taupānga CBR (external link) Niu Taute Wēra – taupānga Ratonga NSW (external link) Te Takiwā o te Raki – Te taupānga Takiuru o Te Takiwā (external link) Kuīniwhenua – Takiuru taupānga Qld (external link) Ahitereiria ki te Tonga – taupānga mySA GOV (external link) Tāhimana – Takiuru taupānga TAS (external link) Wikitōria - taupānga Ratonga Wikitōria (external link) Ahitereiria ki te Uru – taupānga SafeWA (external link) (me whai pea koe i te kāri SIM o Ahitereiria kia whiwhi kaute taupānga SafeWA) Mēnā e māuiui ana koe, e noho ki tō wāhi noho, ka waea atu ki te rata mō ētahi āwhina. Waea atu ki te nama waea ā-Motu mō te rongoā ārai mate korona, KOWHEORI-19, ki te nama waea 1800 020 080 . Kāore he utu mō te waea atu i roto o Ahitereiria. Ka āhei ki te waea atu i ngā haora 24 o te rā, i ngā rā e 7 o te wiki. E haere taratahi-kore koe ki Kūki Airani: me tatū rawa ngā ritenga manene me noho rawa koe ki Aotearoa, ki Ahitereiria rānei ki Kūki Airani rānei mō te 14 rā i mua i tō wehenga atu – arā ka āhei koe ki te haere atu i te 15 o ngā rā mēnā kāore koe i pāngia e te KOWHEORI-19 i roto i te 14 rā i mua i tō wehenga. Mēnā kua pāngia kē koe, me mātua whiwhi tuhi whakaaetanga koe i tētahi kaimahi hauora, e kī ana kua makere katoa atu te mate i a koe mēnā kāore koe i te tiaki kia hoki mai tō whakamātautau KOWHEORI-19. I a koe i Kūki Airani, he ruarua ngā mea kia mahara iho koe e haumaru ake ai koutou ko tō whānau, ko te hapori hoki, i te KOWHEORI-19, pērā i te noho akuaku me te tuhi i ō wāhi taenga atu. He whakamārama anō kei te pae tukutuku a te Kāwanatanga o Kūki Airani (external link) He pūnaha rerekē tō Kūki Airani. Māu rawa e: rēhita ka kawe hoki i te Kāri QR o CookSafe hei takiuru ki ngā wāhi ka tae atu koe whakakāngia te kaiaru Bluetooth o te taupānga CookSafe+. Ka mahi tahi te taupānga CookSafe+ me te taupānga Kaiaru KOWHEORI o Aotearoa. Ko ngā waehere (ngā kī rānei) o Bluetooth ka tonoa mai, ka kohia rānei e te taupānga i tō waea mā tētahi o ngā taupānga nei, ka tuwhera anō ki tētahi atu. Ka mahi ngātahi ngā taupānga nei, ā, ka tangi te tūtei mēnā i pātata koe ki tētahi atu kaiwhakamahi taupānga i pāngia nei e te KOWHEORI-19. Mō ētahi atu whakamārama mō te KĀRI QR o CookSafe (external link) Tāutangia mai te taupānga CookSafe+ ki te Pātaka Taupānga (external link) Tāutangia mai te taupānga CookSafe+ ki Kūkara Purei (external link) Mēnā e māuiui ana koe i Kūki Airani, e noho ki tō wāhi noho, ka ūhia tō kanohi, mēnā he uhi kanohi tōu. Kaua e whakamahi i ngā waka tūmatanui. Waea atu ki te waea-hauora Healthline o Kūki Airani i te nama waea 29667 mō ētahi āwhina. --- Section Separator --- Puka Hāereere Taratahi Kore: Ahitereiria (Australia) → Aotearoa kua whakatārewatia (Suspended) He 7-rā te wā e wātea ana mō ‘ngā rerenga hoki kākāriki’ mai i ngā rohe takiwā katoa o Ahitereiria (hāunga a NSW) kia hoki ai te hunga haere ki te kāinga. Tāutangia ngā taupānga ā-rohe: Te Takiwā Matua o Ahitereiria (ACT) – Tirohia te taupānga CBR (external link) Niu Taute Wēra – taupānga Ratonga NSW (external link) Te Takiwā o te Raki – Te taupānga Takiuru o Te Takiwā (external link) Kuīniwhenua – Takiuru taupānga Qld (external link) Ahitereiria ki te Tonga – taupānga mySA GOV (external link) Tāhimana – Takiuru taupānga TAS (external link) Wikitōria - taupānga Ratonga Wikitōria (external link) Ahitereiria ki te Uru – taupānga SafeWA (external link) (me whai pea koe i te kāri SIM o Ahitereiria kia whiwhi kaute taupānga SafeWA) Mēnā e māuiui ana koe, e noho ki tō wāhi noho, ka waea atu ki te rata mō ētahi āwhina. Waea atu ki te nama waea ā-Motu mō te rongoā ārai mate korona, KOWHEORI-19, ki te nama waea 1800 020 080 . Kāore he utu mō te waea atu i roto o Ahitereiria. Ka āhei ki te waea atu i ngā haora 24 o te rā, i ngā rā e 7 o te wiki. E haere taratahi-kore koe ki Kūki Airani: me tatū rawa ngā ritenga manene me noho rawa koe ki Aotearoa, ki Ahitereiria rānei ki Kūki Airani rānei mō te 14 rā i mua i tō wehenga atu – arā ka āhei koe ki te haere atu i te 15 o ngā rā mēnā kāore koe i pāngia e te KOWHEORI-19 i roto i te 14 rā i mua i tō wehenga. Mēnā kua pāngia kē koe, me mātua whiwhi tuhi whakaaetanga koe i tētahi kaimahi hauora, e kī ana kua makere katoa atu te mate i a koe mēnā kāore koe i te tiaki kia hoki mai tō whakamātautau KOWHEORI-19. I a koe i Kūki Airani, he ruarua ngā mea kia mahara iho koe e haumaru ake ai koutou ko tō whānau, ko te hapori hoki, i te KOWHEORI-19, pērā i te noho akuaku me te tuhi i ō wāhi taenga atu. He whakamārama anō kei te pae tukutuku a te Kāwanatanga o Kūki Airani (external link) He pūnaha rerekē tō Kūki Airani. Māu rawa e: rēhita ka kawe hoki i te Kāri QR o CookSafe hei takiuru ki ngā wāhi ka tae atu koe whakakāngia te kaiaru Bluetooth o te taupānga CookSafe+. Ka mahi tahi te taupānga CookSafe+ me te taupānga Kaiaru KOWHEORI o Aotearoa. Ko ngā waehere (ngā kī rānei) o Bluetooth ka tonoa mai, ka kohia rānei e te taupānga i tō waea mā tētahi o ngā taupānga nei, ka tuwhera anō ki tētahi atu. Ka mahi ngātahi ngā taupānga nei, ā, ka tangi te tūtei mēnā i pātata koe ki tētahi atu kaiwhakamahi taupānga i pāngia nei e te KOWHEORI-19. Mō ētahi atu whakamārama mō te KĀRI QR o CookSafe (external link) Tāutangia mai te taupānga CookSafe+ ki te Pātaka Taupānga (external link) Tāutangia mai te taupānga CookSafe+ ki Kūkara Purei (external link) Mēnā e māuiui ana koe i Kūki Airani, e noho ki tō wāhi noho, ka ūhia tō kanohi, mēnā he uhi kanohi tōu. Kaua e whakamahi i ngā waka tūmatanui. Waea atu ki te waea-hauora Healthline o Kūki Airani i te nama waea 29667 mō ētahi āwhina. --- Section Separator --- Information for Māori Support and information for Pacific Peoples Support and information for disabled people Support your community Alternate formats Translations አማርኛ | Amharic عربي | Arabic Bislama 简体中文 | Chinese (Simplified) 繁體中文 | Chinese (Traditional) Te Reo Māori Kuki ‘Āirani | Cook Islands Māori Español | Spanish دری | Dari فارسی | Farsi Vosa Vakaviti | Fijian ગુજરાતી | Gujarati हिन्दी / Hindi 日本語 | Japanese ကညီ | Karen Te taetae ni Kiribati | Kiribati 한국어 | Korean Bahasa Malaysia | Malay Vagahau Niue | Niuean پښتو | Pashto ਪੰਜਾਬੀ / Punjabi Rohingya Fäeag Rotuḁm | Rotuman Gagana Samoa | Samoan Solomon Aelan Pijin | Solomon Islands Pijin Af-Soomaali | Somali Kiswahili | Swahili Tagalog Te reo Māori தமிழ் | Tamil ภาษาไทย | Thai ትግርኛ | Tigrinya Tok Pisin Te Gagana Tokelau | Tokelauan Lea Faka Tonga | Tongan Te Gana Tuvalu | Tuvaluan اُردُو | Urdu Tiếng Việt | Vietnamese አማርኛ | Amharic عربي | Arabic Bislama 简体中文 | Chinese (Simplified) 繁體中文 | Chinese (Traditional) Te Reo Māori Kuki ‘Āirani | Cook Islands Māori Español | Spanish دری | Dari فارسی | Farsi Vosa Vakaviti | Fijian ગુજરાતી | Gujarati हिन्दी / Hindi 日本語 | Japanese ကညီ | Karen Te taetae ni Kiribati | Kiribati 한국어 | Korean Bahasa Malaysia | Malay Vagahau Niue | Niuean پښتو | Pashto ਪੰਜਾਬੀ / Punjabi Rohingya Fäeag Rotuḁm | Rotuman Gagana Samoa | Samoan Solomon Aelan Pijin | Solomon Islands Pijin Af-Soomaali | Somali Kiswahili | Swahili Tagalog Te reo Māori தமிழ் | Tamil ภาษาไทย | Thai ትግርኛ | Tigrinya Tok Pisin Te Gagana Tokelau | Tokelauan Lea Faka Tonga | Tongan Te Gana Tuvalu | Tuvaluan اُردُو | Urdu Tiếng Việt | Vietnamese

Home Travel Domestic travel Regional travel --- Section Separator --- If you are living at Alert Level 1, you can travel anywhere in New Zealand that is at Alert Level 1 or 2. If you travel to a region that is at Alert Level 2, make sure you follow the restrictions and advice for that region. Use the NZ COVID Tracer app to keep track of where you have been while travelling or on holiday, as you may not recall all the places you've visited. Face coverings legally must be worn: on all public transport — including on long-distance bus and train journeys, as well as most ferries on domestic flights throughout New Zealand by taxi and ride-share drivers — while it is not compulsory for passengers to wear them, we strongly encourage you to. There are exemptions for some people. Wear a face covering If you are sick, stay home and do not travel. If you become unwell while on holiday or travelling away from home, call Healthline on 0800 358 5453 or your doctor to find out if you should get a test. If you are advised to get a test, do so from wherever you are in the country. Do not wait until you get home to get a test. Stay home if you're sick If you are living at Alert Level 2, you can travel anywhere in New Zealand that is at Alert Level 1 or 2, but make sure you do it in a safe way. You legally must wear a face covering when travelling to, from or through an Alert Level 2 region on public transport, including flights. If you travel to a region that is at Alert Level 1, we encourage you to act as if you are carrying your Alert Level with you. Consider avoiding large gatherings, unless you are going to a funeral or tangihanga. If you are sick, please do not travel at all — stay home and get tested. You legally must wear a face covering on public transport and flights. There are exceptions for some people and services. Who needs to wear a face covering Keep records of what travel services you use. Keep track of who you have been in contact with. Keep your distance from groups of people you do not know, where possible. Do not travel: if you have cold, flu or COVID-19 symptoms, are awaiting a test or if you need to self-isolate to events which do not meet the requirements for gatherings at Alert Level 2. Travel between Alert Level areas is strictly limited. Anyone wanting to travel across Alert Level boundaries needs to check whether they are permitted to do so. Alert Level boundary map Personal travel permissions over an Alert Level boundary Business travel permissions over an Alert Level boundary Regional travel You can take a domestic flight for recreation and tourism. Follow guidance to stay safe. Track your journey. Follow all the guidance from transport operators and crew. Sit only in your allocated seat onboard the flight. Maintain physical distancing where you can. You can fly a small plane or glider for recreation if you can do it safely. Keep a record of your journey. Travelling into and out of Northland is a little more difficult while it shares a boundary with Auckland. Find out more about travelling into and out of Northland You can use the Cook Strait ferries for recreation and tourism. Follow guidance to stay safe, track your journey and follow these tips: Follow the instructions and guidance from crew and transport operators. Maintain physical distancing where you can. Comply with any temporary barriers and seat signage telling you where you are allowed to sit. Maintain good hygiene all the time — wash your hands regularly, sneeze or cough into your elbow. Travel into, out of or through an Alert Level 3 area is restricted. These Alert Level boundaries are an important way to manage the risk of the virus spreading, so we can keep our loved ones and communities safe. Anyone wanting to travel across an Alert Level boundary needs to check whether they are eligible to travel. Alert Level boundary map Personal travel permissions over an Alert Level 4 and 3 boundary Business travel permissions over an Alert Level 4 and 3 boundary At Alert Level 3 you can only travel locally, and for allowed reasons. For example, going to work or school if you must, or for shopping or to get exercise. Travelling on public transport Travelling in a private vehicle At Alert Level 4, travel is strictly limited. Air travel will be used only to transport: people travelling home in the first 48 hours after the move to Alert Level 4 people undertaking Alert Level 4 services freight, or for other permitted reasons. Other permitted reasons include: to do necessary work as defined in the Public Health Response Order COVID-19 Public Health Response (Alert Level Requirements) Order (No 9) 2021 (external link) to pick someone up from an airport to pick someone up from managed isolation or quarantine (MIQ) — to pick someone up, you must have a formal letter from MIQ to leave New Zealand to provide urgent care for a child or a person in a critical or terminally ill condition to attend a Court, tribunal, New Zealand Parole Board hearing or another judicial institution. Permitted movement at Alert Level 4 Do not travel if you: have been requested to self-isolate have symptoms of COVID-19 are awaiting a COVID-19 test result. Even if you have been vaccinated, you still need to follow the rules to keep everyone safe. Alert Level boundary map Personal travel permissions over an Alert Level 4 and 3 boundary Business travel permissions over an Alert Level 4 and 3 boundary Non-essential travel, like travel to a second home or holiday home, is not allowed. If you travelled to a second home or bach, you will not be told to return home, however you must stay where you are until restrictions on travel have lifted. The safest place for whānau to be is at home. If you needed to get home after the move to Alert Level 4, you must have arrived by now. --- Section Separator --- If you are living at Alert Level 1, you can travel anywhere in New Zealand that is at Alert Level 1 or 2. If you travel to a region that is at Alert Level 2, make sure you follow the restrictions and advice for that region. Use the NZ COVID Tracer app to keep track of where you have been while travelling or on holiday, as you may not recall all the places you've visited. Face coverings legally must be worn: on all public transport — including on long-distance bus and train journeys, as well as most ferries on domestic flights throughout New Zealand by taxi and ride-share drivers — while it is not compulsory for passengers to wear them, we strongly encourage you to. There are exemptions for some people. Wear a face covering If you are sick, stay home and do not travel. If you become unwell while on holiday or travelling away from home, call Healthline on 0800 358 5453 or your doctor to find out if you should get a test. If you are advised to get a test, do so from wherever you are in the country. Do not wait until you get home to get a test. Stay home if you're sick --- Section Separator --- If you are living at Alert Level 2, you can travel anywhere in New Zealand that is at Alert Level 1 or 2, but make sure you do it in a safe way. You legally must wear a face covering when travelling to, from or through an Alert Level 2 region on public transport, including flights. If you travel to a region that is at Alert Level 1, we encourage you to act as if you are carrying your Alert Level with you. Consider avoiding large gatherings, unless you are going to a funeral or tangihanga. If you are sick, please do not travel at all — stay home and get tested. You legally must wear a face covering on public transport and flights. There are exceptions for some people and services. Who needs to wear a face covering Keep records of what travel services you use. Keep track of who you have been in contact with. Keep your distance from groups of people you do not know, where possible. Do not travel: if you have cold, flu or COVID-19 symptoms, are awaiting a test or if you need to self-isolate to events which do not meet the requirements for gatherings at Alert Level 2. Travel between Alert Level areas is strictly limited. Anyone wanting to travel across Alert Level boundaries needs to check whether they are permitted to do so. Alert Level boundary map Personal travel permissions over an Alert Level boundary Business travel permissions over an Alert Level boundary Regional travel You can take a domestic flight for recreation and tourism. Follow guidance to stay safe. Track your journey. Follow all the guidance from transport operators and crew. Sit only in your allocated seat onboard the flight. Maintain physical distancing where you can. You can fly a small plane or glider for recreation if you can do it safely. Keep a record of your journey. Travelling into and out of Northland is a little more difficult while it shares a boundary with Auckland. Find out more about travelling into and out of Northland You can use the Cook Strait ferries for recreation and tourism. Follow guidance to stay safe, track your journey and follow these tips: Follow the instructions and guidance from crew and transport operators. Maintain physical distancing where you can. Comply with any temporary barriers and seat signage telling you where you are allowed to sit. Maintain good hygiene all the time — wash your hands regularly, sneeze or cough into your elbow. --- Section Separator --- Travel into, out of or through an Alert Level 3 area is restricted. These Alert Level boundaries are an important way to manage the risk of the virus spreading, so we can keep our loved ones and communities safe. Anyone wanting to travel across an Alert Level boundary needs to check whether they are eligible to travel. Alert Level boundary map Personal travel permissions over an Alert Level 4 and 3 boundary Business travel permissions over an Alert Level 4 and 3 boundary At Alert Level 3 you can only travel locally, and for allowed reasons. For example, going to work or school if you must, or for shopping or to get exercise. Travelling on public transport Travelling in a private vehicle --- Section Separator --- At Alert Level 4, travel is strictly limited. Air travel will be used only to transport: people travelling home in the first 48 hours after the move to Alert Level 4 people undertaking Alert Level 4 services freight, or for other permitted reasons. Other permitted reasons include: to do necessary work as defined in the Public Health Response Order COVID-19 Public Health Response (Alert Level Requirements) Order (No 9) 2021 (external link) to pick someone up from an airport to pick someone up from managed isolation or quarantine (MIQ) — to pick someone up, you must have a formal letter from MIQ to leave New Zealand to provide urgent care for a child or a person in a critical or terminally ill condition to attend a Court, tribunal, New Zealand Parole Board hearing or another judicial institution. Permitted movement at Alert Level 4 Do not travel if you: have been requested to self-isolate have symptoms of COVID-19 are awaiting a COVID-19 test result. Even if you have been vaccinated, you still need to follow the rules to keep everyone safe. Alert Level boundary map Personal travel permissions over an Alert Level 4 and 3 boundary Business travel permissions over an Alert Level 4 and 3 boundary Non-essential travel, like travel to a second home or holiday home, is not allowed. If you travelled to a second home or bach, you will not be told to return home, however you must stay where you are until restrictions on travel have lifted. The safest place for whānau to be is at home. If you needed to get home after the move to Alert Level 4, you must have arrived by now. --- Section Separator --- Public transport Private vehicles Regional travel Walking, cycling and other active travel Travelling across Alert Level boundaries
Home Travel Domestic travel Private vehicles --- Section Separator --- Help limit the spread of any virus by staying at home if you are unwell. If that's not possible, call Healthline for guidance first on 0800 358 5453 . Wash your hands before and after travelling. Cough and sneeze into your elbow. Where possible, use hand sanitiser before and after you enter or exit your vehicle. When you get home, wash your hands for at least 20 seconds with soap and water and dry them thoroughly. At Alert Level 1, you can travel but try to do it in a safe way. If you're unwell, stay at home. Keep track of who you have been in contact with. Practise good hygiene habits. Alert Level boundary map Personal travel permissions over an Alert Level boundary Business travel permissions over an Alert Level boundary Regional travel At Alert Level 3, travel is restricted and only allowed for permitted movement in your local area, for example going to work or school if you need to, shopping or getting exercise. You can travel in a private car only for the following reasons: accessing local services and businesses going to work or school, but only if you cannot work or learn at home low-risk exercise in your local area visiting people in your bubble travelling to permitted gatherings. Your local area means the area near your home that you regularly visit for essential services. What is considered local will differ depending on where you live. City dwellers may have a supermarket or dairy close by. If you live rurally, you may need to take a drive to reach these. If you're unwell, stay at home. We recommend you only travel in your car with people from your bubble. Practise good hygiene habits. Keep track of who you have been in contact with. Do not travel across an Alert Level boundary, unless your travel is permitted or you have an exemption. Personal and business travel permissions for crossing an Alert Level boundary Do not travel if you have been asked to self-isolate. Remember, any unnecessary travel may spread COVID-19. The safest place for whānau to be is at home. If you are an Alert Level 4 worker and you are permitted to leave home to work, you can use a private car to get there. You may be asked to show who you work for so you can prove you have a reason to travel. We recommend your employer provide you with a letter to confirm: your name that you are providing an Alert Level 4 business or service, and your destination. If someone in your household bubble needs help to travel for essential personal movement, you can travel with them. You can travel with them by any method, like public transport, taxis or ride-shares, or private car. Home Travel Domestic travel Public transport --- Section Separator --- Everyone 12 years and older legally must wear a face covering on public transport at all Alert Levels. Drivers of taxi and ride-share services legally must wear face coverings. Passengers of taxi and ride-share services legally must wear a face covering at Alert Level 2 and above, but are only encouraged at Alert Level 1. Drivers and transport operators will not stop people without face coverings from boarding public transport. This is because some people will have legitimate reasons for not wearing a face covering. Face covering exemptions for some people and services However, where possible, drivers will be encouraging passengers to wear a face covering. Who needs to wear a face covering Wash your hands before and after travelling. Cough and sneeze into your elbow. Where possible, use hand sanitiser before and after you enter or exit public transport. When you get home, wash your hands for at least 20 seconds with soap and water and dry them thoroughly. Scan the QR code or keep a record of which service you travelled with and when. This will help with contract tracing for any cases in your community. At Alert Level 1, you can travel but try to do it in a safe way. We recommend you do not use public transport if you are unwell. Always wear a face covering on public transport and domestic flights, unless you have an exemption. Face covering exemptions for some people and services Practise good hygiene habits. Scan in or keep a record of which service you travel. Public transport operators legally must display QR code posters to help you keep track of where you’ve been. We recommend you use the NZ COVID Tracer app to do this, or another way that works for you. Drivers of taxis and ride-share servic es legally must wear a face covering, and passengers are strongly encouraged to wear a face covering too. Drivers legally must display QR code posters to help you keep track of where you’ve been. We recommend you use the NZ COVID Tracer app to do this, or another way that works for you. Living at Alert Level 1, including keeping your distance, wearing face coverings and contact tracing for businesses At Alert Level 2, you can travel, but make sure you do it in a safe way. To help achieve physical distancing, numbers of people on public transport are limited. You must be seated when you are on public transport — the service will not be able to carry passengers who are standing. This rule does not apply to: dedicated school buses the Cook Strait Ferry. If you think your service may be full, you could plan your journey to travel later or earlier than your usual time. it is a good idea to speak with your employer to see if you can change your work hours, or work flexibly. Remember to be kind and respectful to drivers and your fellow passengers. Do not travel to events which do not meet the requirements for gatherings at Alert Level 2. You must keep 1 metre apart from everyone on public transport and at transport stations, where possible. There are some situations where this is not possible, for example in a taxi or ride-share. Even if you have been vaccinated, you still need to follow the rules to keep everyone safe. Remember, any unnecessary travel may spread COVID-19. Always wear a face covering on public transport, unless you have an exemption. Face covering exemptions for some people and services Practise good hygiene habits. Scan in with the NZ COVID Tracer app or keep a record of which service you travel. To help achieve physical distancing, numbers of people on public transport are limited. You must be seated when you are on public transport — the service will not be able to carry passengers who are standing. This rule does not apply to: dedicated school buses the Cook Strait Ferry. If you think your service may be full, you could plan your journey to travel later or earlier than your usual time. it is a good idea to speak with your employer to see if you can change your work hours, or work flexibly. Remember to be kind and respectful to drivers and your fellow passengers. Permitted movement at Alert Level 4 Non-essential travel, like travel to a second home or holiday home, is not allowed. If you travelled to a second home or bach, you will not be told to return home, however you must stay where you are until restrictions on travel have lifted. The safest place for whānau to be is at home. If you are an Alert Level 4 worker and you are permitted to leave home to work, you can use public transport to get there. You may be asked to show who you work for so you can show you have a reason to travel. We recommend your employer provide you with a letter to confirm: your name that you are providing an Alert Level 4 business or service, and your destination. Permitted movement within Alert Level 4 You can use any travel method to get to your COVID-19 vaccine appointments. If someone in your household bubble needs help to travel for essential personal movement, you can travel with them. You can travel with them by any method, like public transport, taxis or ride-shares, or private car. Alert Level boundary map Personal travel permissions over an Alert Level boundary Business travel permissions over an Alert Level boundary Regional travel If you needed to get home after the move to Alert Level 4, you must have arrived by now. If you are unwell and you need to travel, you should use private transport if possible. If private transport is not available, call Healthline on 0800 358 5453 for advice. --- Section Separator --- Public transport Private vehicles Regional travel Walking, cycling and other active travel Travelling across Alert Level boundaries
Home Travel Domestic travel Walking, cycling and other active travel --- Section Separator --- Personal walks and other active travel like cycling or scootering are fine, as long as you keep 2 metres away from anyone not in your household bubble. You can use shared bicycles or scooters. Full list of reasons to travel at Alert Level 4 | transport.govt.nz (external link) Stick to simple outdoor exercise and avoid areas where you can get injured or lost. It is important emergency services remain available to support the response to COVID-19. Remember, any unnecessary travel may spread COVID-19. If you are unwell, stay at home. Keep track of who you have been in contact with. Practise good hygiene habits. Do not travel if you have been asked to self-isolate. Even if you have been vaccinated, you still need to follow the rules to keep everyone safe. Sports and recreation at Alert Level 4 If you are an Alert Level 4 worker and you are permitted to leave home to work, you can walk, cycle or use other active travel like scooters to get there. You may be asked to show who you work for so you can prove you have a reason to travel. We recommend your employer provide you with a letter to confirm: your name that you are providing an Alert Level 4 business or service, and your destination. Home Travel Foreign nationals in New Zealand --- Section Separator --- You can use international air services to travel home. However, there may be limited options available. If you cannot secure a ticket, contact your country’s high commission, embassy or consulate in New Zealand. You may be required to self-isolate or enter managed isolation when you arrive, so it is best to check it now. Embassies will be able to help you find information. You may find that you are not allowed to transit through certain countries. Embassies will be able to help you. Even if you did not book your travel through a travel agent, they can let you know what is happening with your flight, or how to book a flight. Use airline and airport websites to check your flight. Airline schedules have been disrupted so check that your flight is going ahead as scheduled. Airline staff at airports are very busy trying to assist travellers, so make sure you book your flight before you arrive at the airport. Do not turn up at the airport more than 3 hours before departure. You are responsible for understanding how to meet the conditions of your visa in New Zealand at all times. Verify the details of current New Zealand visas | immigration.govt.nz (external link) Immigration NZ provides information on visa extensions, new visa expiry dates and changes to visa conditions. Visit the Immigration NZ website to check information about your visa. Visa extensions and visa conditions | immigration.govt.nz (external link) If you require assistance, you can contact your embassy, high commission or consular representative. Find an embassy or foreign representative to New Zealand | mfat.govt.nz (external link) Help is available for eligible foreign nationals who are stranded in New Zealand and are experiencing serious financial hardship due to COVID-19. Financial support for foreign nationals stranded in in New Zealand --- Section Separator --- You can use international air services to travel home. However, there may be limited options available. Financial support for foreign nationals stranded in in New Zealand --- Section Separator --- Quarantine-free travel International travel and transit Pre-departure tests to enter New Zealand Domestic travel Permitted travel at different Alert Levels New Zealanders overseas Foreign nationals in New Zealand Reconnecting New Zealanders to the World Signs and posters for travelling safely
Entry to New Zealand is strictly controlled to help prevent the spread of COVID-19. Managed isolation and quarantine (MIQ) is an important part of our border measures to keep COVID-19 out of New Zealand. Travel from 'very high risk' countries to New Zealand is currently restricted. The New Zealand Government has transit arrangements with some countries to make it easier for each country’s citizens to get home. Many borders around the world are closed to people who are not citizens and permanent residents of that country. You may be asked to complete the Survey of New Zealand Arrivals if you have recently arrived in New Zealand. Most travellers legally must have a negative COVID-19 test to enter New Zealand. Find out more about New Zealand's pre-departure testing requirements. --- Section Separator --- Entry to New Zealand is strictly controlled to help prevent the spread of COVID-19. Managed isolation and quarantine (MIQ) is an important part of our border measures to keep COVID-19 out of New Zealand. Travel from 'very high risk' countries to New Zealand is currently restricted. The New Zealand Government has transit arrangements with some countries to make it easier for each country’s citizens to get home. Many borders around the world are closed to people who are not citizens and permanent residents of that country. You may be asked to complete the Survey of New Zealand Arrivals if you have recently arrived in New Zealand. Most travellers legally must have a negative COVID-19 test to enter New Zealand. Find out more about New Zealand's pre-departure testing requirements.
Home Travel International travel and transit Leaving New Zealand --- Section Separator --- Before travelling overseas we recommend you check the requirements of the country you are travelling to. Check: the official website of the country you wish to enter or transit, or that country’s diplomatic representative in New Zealand. Many countries require travellers to self-isolate for 14 days on arrival, or have a negative COVID-19 test result before they can travel. New Zealanders are advised not to travel overseas at this time. The New Zealand Government has raised its travel advice to “do not travel” — the highest level — for all destinations except the Cook Islands. For the Cook Islands, the New Zealand Government advises you to “exercise increased caution”. Travel advice at SafeTravel (external link) The New Zealand Government is urging any New Zealanders currently travelling overseas to register with SafeTravel. If you register, you will receive notification of any changes made to travel advice. Register your details with SafeTravel (external link) New Zealanders overseas If you are a foreign national travelling in New Zealand, we recommend you consider returning home as soon as you are able to. Advice for foreign nationals in New Zealand When you are vaccinated in New Zealand, you get a purple vaccination card. These cards have basic information about your vaccination appointment, but they may not be recognised as proof of your vaccination by overseas countries. If you need written confirmation of your COVID-19 vaccination for international travel, you can request a letter from the Ministry of Health. Make sure you check the requirements of the country you are travelling to and find out what vaccination proof they need. Request proof of vaccination (external link) New Zealand has quarantine-free travel arrangements with Australia and the Cook Islands. Due to the recent community outbreak, quarantine-free travel to Australia and the Cook Islands is paused. Quarantine-free travel with the Cook Islands New Zealand safe travel zone | homeaffairs.gov.au (external link) Some countries require travellers to confirm a negative COVID-19 test before they leave New Zealand. You can check the requirements of the country you are travelling to, by contacting their local high commission, embassy or consulate in New Zealand. As soon as your travel plans are confirmed, contact Healthline or your doctor. Find out when you can go in for a COVID-19 test. The test needs to be taken as close as possible to your date of travel — check the timing that applies to your country. You may need to pay for the test yourself, at the time. Your test will be sent to a local laboratory, which will provide a result to your doctor or you directly. A health provider will let you know the result of the test. It can take several days for test results to be available, so make sure you do not leave it too late. Assuming the test is negative, you will be given a hard-copy document with the results to take to the airport. In the unlikely event the test is positive, your health provider will talk with you about what happens next. Take your negative test results with you to airport check-in. You may need to show your results to customs or immigration on arrival at your destination. Further travel advice from the Ministry of Health (external link) The New Zealand Government has transit arrangements with a number of countries to make it easier for each country’s citizens to get home. Transit agreements that say who may transit through New Zealand are published by Immigration New Zealand. You should also check if you need to apply for a transit exemption from Managed Isolation and Quarantine. Transit arrangements from Immigration New Zealand (external link) (external link) Exemptions to transit through New Zealand, and how to apply (external link) (external link) --- Section Separator --- Before travelling overseas we recommend you check the requirements of the country you are travelling to. Home Travel International travel and transit Managed isolation and quarantine (MIQ) --- Section Separator --- Due to the continuing community outbreak, MIQ is extending the temporary pause on the release and re-release of rooms for a short period of time. Pause of vouchers extended | miq.govt.nz (external link) Almost all travellers are legally required to have a voucher confirming their place in managed isolation before boarding their flight. Those returning to New Zealand have a responsibility to do their part to stop COVID-19 spreading. If you have been vaccinated against COVID-19, you still need to secure a voucher and complete 14 days in our managed isolation and quarantine (MIQ) facilities. By completing 14 days in MIQ, we can ensure people do not have COVID-19 before returning to our communities. Over 160,000 people have completed their MIQ stay safely, and have returned to their loved ones and friends. When you arrive in New Zealand you are checked for symptoms of COVID-19. If you: do not have symptoms, you will isolate at a managed isolation facility have symptoms or test positive for COVID-19, you will isolate in a quarantine facility or separate area. Both types of facilities are located within hotels. You are legally required to have a voucher before flying to New Zealand. Your voucher allocates you a place in an MIQ facility. Airlines will not be permitted to board you if you do not have a voucher, unless you are exempt from using the Managed Isolation Allocation System. If you are flying quarantine-free to New Zealand, then you will not enter MIQ and so you do not need a voucher. Get your voucher by registering on the Managed Isolation Allocation System. Register for a voucher for MIQ (external link) The emergency allocation process exists for limited situations that require urgent travel to New Zealand within the next 14 days. You can apply for an emergency allocation if you cannot book your preferred date in the Managed Isolation Allocation System, and you meet the eligibility criteria. You can request an emergency allocation if: you are legally entitled to enter New Zealand under our current border settings your travel is time-critical — within the next 14 days you have registered in the Managed Isolation Allocation System and you have not been able to book an allocation for the date you require urgent travel your circumstances fall within 1 of the 2 categories permitted, and you have attached evidence to support your application. The MIQ website has details about the travel categories permitted for emergency allocation, and what supporting evidence you need. Very few emergency allocation requests will be granted. We encourage you to book in early to the Managed Isolation Allocation System, as this is the best way to guarantee your place. Emergency allocation requests | miq.govt.nz (external link) You do not have to pay for a voucher. However, some people will be charged for their stay in MIQ. The Government recovers some of the costs for MIQ. This is to share the costs in a way that fairly reflects the benefits to both the New Zealand public of having a robust system, and those who leave and enter the country. Costs for MIQ, and who needs to pay | miq.govt.nz (external link) Most people will be tested for COVID-19 around day 0/1 of their stay — within 24 hours of arriving. You may be asked to remain in your room until the result of the test is known. If you are symptomatic when you arrive, you will go straight into a quarantine facility. If the result of your day 0/1 test is positive, you will be moved to a quarantine facility. If you test negative, you will stay in your managed isolation facility to complete the rest of your stay. You will be tested for COVID-19 again around day 3 and day 12 of your stay. If you are on the same floor, and in the vicinity of a confirmed day 0/1 or day 3 case of COVID-19, you will also be tested at day 6 or 7. This is an additional test, introduced from 25 August. There are no exemptions from quarantine for people with COVID-19 symptoms. Managed isolation is an important part of keeping COVID-19 out of New Zealand, but we know there are people facing exceptional circumstances. Exemptions from managed isolation are approved in very few circumstances. Applications for exemptions are considered on a case-by-case basis and the threshold for approval is very high. An exemption will only be approved where we can be confident that the health risk of transmission is very low. Any exemption is from being in managed isolation, not from having to isolate. The managed isolation and quarantine website has information about exemptions, including: what an exemption is types of exemption available how to apply Apply for an exemption from staying in MIQ | miq.govt.nz (external link) --- Section Separator --- Due to the continuing community outbreak, MIQ is extending the temporary pause on the release and re-release of rooms for a short period of time. Home Travel International travel and transit Survey of New Zealand Arrivals --- Section Separator --- Get the results for arrivals from 1 August 2020 to 9 January 2021 We are undertaking a survey of people arriving in or returning to New Zealand to get a better idea of the potential impact recent arrivals may have on government services and the economy. This survey is called the Survey of New Zealand Arrivals. The New Zealand Government would like to better understand recent arrivals in New Zealand, for example who they are, where they have come from and what their circumstances are. This information will help the Government identify the needs of recent arrivals, and what this could mean for government services and policy development. The Survey of New Zealand Arrivals is collecting information to help inform government policy. It does not cover the managed isolation and quarantine (MIQ) process. If you have any feedback or suggestions about your experience in an MIQ facility, or you want to make a complaint, you can do this through the MIQ website. Give feedback about your experience in MIQ (external link) The COVID-19 Group, which is part of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment (MBIE) are leading the survey. Martin Jenkins and Associates Ltd has been contracted to carry out the survey on behalf of these agencies. Martin Jenkins is an independent consultancy service. You will be invited to do the survey if you have recently arrived in New Zealand and you are 18 or over. You will be contacted by email. Your name was selected to complete the survey because you are a recent arrival to New Zealand. You provided your contact details to the Government on arrival into New Zealand. As an agent of MBIE, Martin Jenkins Ltd will be given your name and email address to contact you to complete this survey. They will hold your contact details for up to 4 months, before deleting them. You can choose if you want to complete the survey, and you can withdraw at any time without having to give a reason. The survey will take about 12 minutes to complete, and you can do it on a computer/laptop, tablet or smartphone. You do not need to prepare anything before you complete the survey. If you are having trouble getting the survey link to open, or having other technical difficulties, email Martin Jenkins Ltd at matthew.fanselow@martinjenkins.co.nz Your answers will be combined with the answers from other people who have completed the survey. Because your answers are grouped with others, you cannot be identified. However, if you agree to take part in further research, your contact details will be sent to the research team at MBIE. The information will be held securely by MBIE, and will be deleted after 12 months. Martin Jenkins Ltd will delete your name and contact details after it has sent them to MBIE. The lead agencies and any researchers working with the data cannot access any identifying information about you or other survey participants. The survey data will be held in the Stats NZ Integrated Data Infrastructure (IDI) secure environment and no information will be published in a form that could identify individuals. Stats NZ may link the information to other data sources for research or statistical purposes only. How Stats NZ keeps IDI data safe and anonymous (external link) You can request a copy of your survey answers. You can also ask for them to be corrected, but you need to do this in the same calendar month that you complete the survey. Request a copy of your answers by emailing Martin Jenkins Ltd at matthew.fanselow@martinjenkins.co.nz If you have any questions about this survey, email Martin Jenkins Ltd at matthew.fanselow@martinjenkins.co.nz If you would like to contact someone at MBIE about this survey, email the MBIE research team at NZarrivals.survey@mbie.govt.nz MBIE has published the provisional results for arrivals into New Zealand between 1 August 2020 and 9 January 2021. The Survey of New Zealand Arrivals collects data on the characteristics and intentions of those arriving in Aotearoa New Zealand during the COVID-19 border closures. Results from Survey of New Zealand Arrivals for 1 August 2020 to 9 January 2021 [PDF, 895 KB] MBIE will publish the survey results for those people arriving between 10 January and 14 April 2021 when it’s available. --- Section Separator --- Get the results for arrivals from 1 August 2020 to 9 January 2021 --- Section Separator --- We are undertaking a survey of people arriving in or returning to New Zealand to get a better idea of the potential impact recent arrivals may have on government services and the economy. The survey data will be held in the Stats NZ Integrated Data Infrastructure (IDI) secure environment and no information will be published in a form that could identify individuals. Stats NZ may link the information to other data sources for research or statistical purposes only. How Stats NZ keeps IDI data safe and anonymous (external link) You can request a copy of your survey answers. You can also ask for them to be corrected, but you need to do this in the same calendar month that you complete the survey. Request a copy of your answers by emailing Martin Jenkins Ltd at matthew.fanselow@martinjenkins.co.nz --- Section Separator --- If you have any questions about this survey, email Martin Jenkins Ltd at matthew.fanselow@martinjenkins.co.nz If you would like to contact someone at MBIE about this survey, email the MBIE research team at NZarrivals.survey@mbie.govt.nz --- Section Separator --- MBIE has published the provisional results for arrivals into New Zealand between 1 August 2020 and 9 January 2021. The Survey of New Zealand Arrivals collects data on the characteristics and intentions of those arriving in Aotearoa New Zealand during the COVID-19 border closures. Results from Survey of New Zealand Arrivals for 1 August 2020 to 9 January 2021 [PDF, 895 KB] --- Section Separator --- MBIE will publish the survey results for those people arriving between 10 January and 14 April 2021 when it’s available. --- Section Separator --- Travel to New Zealand Managed isolation and quarantine (MIQ) Travel restrictions for very high risk countries Transit through New Zealand Leaving New Zealand Survey of New Zealand Arrivals Pre-departure tests to enter New Zealand
Home Travel International travel and transit Transit through New Zealand --- Section Separator --- If you pass through New Zealand on your way to another country and you do not plan to stay, you are a transit passenger. You can only transit New Zealand through Auckland International Airport, where you must stay in the transit area of the airport. You cannot apply to enter New Zealand. You can remain in transit for up to 24 hours. If you need to stay longer than 24 hours, you are not a transit passenger and you need to apply to enter New Zealand. New Zealand border entry requirements | immigration.govt.nz (external link) You may need a New Zealand Electronic Travel Authority (NZeTA) or transit visa to transit New Zealand. Some people do not need an NZeTA or transit visa. Immigration NZ explains who can transit through New Zealand, and who needs an NZeTA or transit visa. Who can transit New Zealand | immigration.govt.nz (external link) Currently, you cannot transit New Zealand on your way to or from Australia. If you arrive in New Zealand on a non-quarantine-free flight, you must spend 14 days in a managed isolation or quarantine (MIQ) facility before you can travel on to Australia. If you arrive in New Zealand on a quarantine-free flight, for example from the Cook Islands, you still must spend 14 days in New Zealand before you can continue your journey to Australia. Managed isolation and quarantine (MIQ) Only travellers from some countries are allowed to transit New Zealand to China. Who can transit New Zealand to China | immigration.govt.nz (external link) If you’re entering New Zealand for longer than 24 hours, you are not a transit passenger. You must have a valid visa that permits your entry into New Zealand. What you need to do depends on if you’re entering New Zealand: for 24 to 72 hours, or for longer than 72 hours, but less than 14 days. What to do if you’re staying in NZ longer than 24 hours | miq.govt.nz (external link) New Zealand border entry requirements | immigration.govt.nz (external link) You do not need to get a pre-departure test if you’re transiting New Zealand. However, you will likely need a pre-departure test for your final destination and other countries on your journey. You may also need to meet health requirements at your final destination. It is your responsibility to make sure you understand the requirements of the countries you’re travelling though and your final destination. You cannot transit New Zealand if you do not meet all the requirements of your final destination. --- Section Separator --- If you pass through New Zealand on your way to another country and you do not plan to stay, you are a transit passenger. You can only transit New Zealand through Auckland International Airport, where you must stay in the transit area of the airport. You cannot apply to enter New Zealand. You can remain in transit for up to 24 hours. If you need to stay longer than 24 hours, you are not a transit passenger and you need to apply to enter New Zealand. Some people do not need an NZeTA or transit visa. Immigration NZ explains who can transit through New Zealand, and who needs an NZeTA or transit visa. Home Travel International travel and transit Travel restrictions for very high risk countries --- Section Separator --- The Government has created a ‘very high risk’ country category that will significantly reduce the number of people with COVID-19 flying to New Zealand. The following countries currently meet the threshold of being very high risk: Brazil Fiji India Indonesia Pakistan Papua New Guinea We added Fiji and Indonesia to this list on 11 August. Travel will be restricted from Fiji and Indonesia from 11:59pm (NZT) on 15 August 2021. Travellers to New Zealand from very high risk countries are temporarily restricted to: New Zealand citizens partners and dependent children of New Zealand citizens, or parents of dependent children who are New Zealand citizens, together with any children of those parents who are not New Zealand citizens. Dependent children are children under 18 years old. Partners of New Zealand citizens can be a spouse, civil union partner or de facto partner. If you are a non-New Zealand citizen, you must hold a valid visa to enter New Zealand. Reasons you can travel to New Zealand at Immigration NZ (external link) All other travellers, including people holding residence class visas, must spend at least 14 days outside of very high risk countries before flying to New Zealand. You can transit through a very high risk country without having to spend 14 days outside the country before you travel to New Zealand. There is no limit on the amount of time you may spend transiting through a very high risk country, but you must stay airside. This means you will stay at the airport and not enter the country. All travellers from Fiji can transit New Zealand to other countries. You must stay airside, which means you will stay at the airport and not enter the country. You must spend less than 24 hours in transit in New Zealand. All travellers from very high risk countries (except Fiji) must have evidence of negative nasopharyngeal RT-PCR (PCR) test result from a government-approved laboratory. The test must be taken within 72 hours of departure. Pre-departure tests to enter New Zealand The Ministry of Health publishes lists of laboratories in very high risk countries that are approved to conduct COVID-19 tests. Lists of approved laboratories (external link) Travellers from Fiji do not need to get pre-departure tests. This is because it is not easy to access tests and there are delays in receiving results. The Director-General of Health may grant exemptions for humanitarian reasons. You can find out more about the exemptions process at the Ministry of Health website. Apply for an exemption (external link) The Government considers the following factors, among others, when deciding to designate a country as very high risk: Whether cases in the country are rising rapidly and the predominant strain, for example the Delta variant. The level of confidence in the country’s testing and other public health measures, such as vaccination coverage rates. The risk to New Zealand's borders. Resurgence of COVID-19 is happening in a number of countries, and there are further waves of infections in many countries as new variants of the COVID-19 virus arise. This means New Zealand expects to see more returnees with COVID-19 from these areas. This increase in cases will place pressure on our managed isolation and quarantine (MIQ) systems and increase the risk of a community outbreak. This is particularly important as countries deal with the Delta variant of COVID-19. The New Zealand Government has responded by creating a very high risk country category that will significantly reduce the number of people with COVID-19 flying to New Zealand. The Government will review this decision regularly. If you are a New Zealander in a very high risk country, make sure you register your travel and contact details with SafeTravel. Register at SafeTravel to get the latest travel advice for the country you're in (external link) In the 14 days before leaving there are things you can do to help reduce your risk of being exposed to COVID-19 and bringing it to New Zealand with you: Avoid going to high-risk events like parties, social gatherings or crowded places. Avoid contact with people who have COVID-19 or who are contacts of people with COVID-19. Stay home as much as possible to limit your contact with other people. Wash and dry your hands often, cough into your elbow and avoid touching your face. Keep your distance from people you do not know. Wear a face covering when you cannot keep your distance. We added information in Fijian and Indonesian and updated the other languages on 11 August 2021. We added information in Tok Pisin on 12 August. --- Section Separator --- The Government has created a ‘very high risk’ country category that will significantly reduce the number of people with COVID-19 flying to New Zealand. --- Section Separator --- The following countries currently meet the threshold of being very high risk: Brazil Fiji India Indonesia Pakistan Papua New Guinea We added Fiji and Indonesia to this list on 11 August. Home Travel International travel and transit Travel to New Zealand --- Section Separator --- The New Zealand borders are closed to almost all travellers to help stop the spread of COVID-19. The travel restrictions apply to all arrivals into New Zealand by air or sea. You have a legal right to come to New Zealand if you are: a New Zealand citizen a New Zealand resident with valid travel conditions. Travel from very high risk countries is temporarily restricted to New Zealand citizens, partners and dependent children of New Zealand citizens, and parents of dependent children who are New Zealand citizens. The following countries currently meet the threshold of being very high risk: Brazil Fiji India Indonesia Pakistan Papua New Guinea Travel restrictions for very high risk countries You may be able to travel to New Zealand while the border is closed if we consider you have a critical purpose to travel. Critical purpose reasons to travel | immigration.govt.nz (external link) Most people who are not New Zealand citizens or residents legally must get approval from Immigration NZ before travelling to New Zealand. Some people do not need to request to travel. Information from Immigration NZ: Immigration during COVID-19 (external link) New Zealand border entry requirements (external link) New Zealand has quarantine-free travel arrangements with some countries. Travelling quarantine-free means you do not have to enter managed isolation. Normal immigration rules apply for quarantine-free travel. Travel quarantine-free to New Zealand from some countries There are exceptions for some vessels. These include cargo ships, fishing vessels unloading catch, and ships coming from Antarctica. Guidance for the maritime sector | health.govt.nz (external link) Most people must have a negative COVID-19 pre-departure test result before travelling to New Zealand. Some people do not need to get pre-departure tests. Requirements for pre-departure testing for travellers to New Zealand It is important that people returning to New Zealand do their part to stop COVID-19 spreading in New Zealand. If you are returning to New Zealand, you legally must complete at least 14 days of managed isolation or quarantine, unless you are arriving under quarantine-free travel. You will also be tested for COVID-19 during your stay in a facility. Managed isolation and quarantine You are legally required to have a voucher before flying to New Zealand. Your voucher allocates you a place in a managed isolation facility. Airlines will not be permitted to board you if you do not have a voucher, unless you are exempt from using the Managed Isolation Allocation System. Register for a voucher for managed isolation (external link) Space in managed isolation is extremely limited. An emergency allocation process exists for limited situations that require urgent travel to New Zealand within the next 14 days. Very few emergency allocation requests will be granted. We encourage you to book in early to the Managed Isolation Allocation System, as this is the best way to guarantee your place. Who can request an emergency allocation and how to apply | miq.govt.nz (external link) Quarantine-free travel allows you to travel to and enter countries that are participating in a quarantine-free travel arrangement without needing to enter managed isolation or quarantine when you arrive. You can travel to New Zealand quarantine-free from: the Cook Islands Niue Quarantine-free travel Quarantine-free travel from Australia to New Zealand is suspended from 11:59pm on 23 July 2021. International transit through New Zealand If you are a New Zealand citizen abroad you can get emergency consular assistance. You can access support for situations like lost or stolen passports, death, health issues and law infringements. New Zealand cannot influence or guarantee another country or airline’s entry, exit or transit requirements. We also cannot help you book a commercial flight. Get emergency consular help by calling: +64 99 20 20 20 if you are outside New Zealand 0800 30 10 30 if you are in New Zealand. Home Travel New Zealanders overseas --- Section Separator --- Plan your travel to New Zealand The emergency allocation process exists for limited situations that require urgent travel to New Zealand within the next 14 days. You can apply for an emergency allocation if you cannot book your preferred date in the Managed Isolation Allocation System, and you meet the eligibility criteria. You can request an emergency allocation if: you are legally entitled to enter New Zealand under our current border settings your travel is time-critical — within the next 14 days you have registered in the Managed Isolation Allocation System and you have not been able to book an allocation for the date you require urgent travel your circumstances fall within 1 of the 2 categories permitted, and you have attached evidence to support your application. The MIQ website has details about the travel categories permitted for emergency allocation, and what supporting evidence you need. Very few emergency allocation requests will be granted. We encourage you to book in early to the Managed Isolation Allocation System, as this is the best way to guarantee your place. Emergency allocation requests | miq.govt.nz (external link) The New Zealand Government is urging any New Zealanders currently travelling overseas to register with SafeTravel. If you register, you will receive notification of any changes made to travel advice for the country or region you are in. Remember to keep your details and travel plans up to date. Alert Level boundaries help stop the spread of the virus. Travel across Alert Level boundaries is strictly limited, and you need to check whether you can travel. Personal movement within Alert Level 3 is limited, except for the permitted reasons. Personal movement at Alert Level 4 is limited, except for the permitted reasons. Personal travel between Alert Level areas is strictly limited to stop the spread of the virus. Business and work travel across Alert Level boundaries is strictly limited to stop the spread of the virus. --- Section Separator --- Alert Level boundaries help stop the spread of the virus. Travel across Alert Level boundaries is strictly limited, and you need to check whether you can travel. Personal movement within Alert Level 3 is limited, except for the permitted reasons. Personal movement at Alert Level 4 is limited, except for the permitted reasons. Personal travel between Alert Level areas is strictly limited to stop the spread of the virus. Business and work travel across Alert Level boundaries is strictly limited to stop the spread of the virus.
Refinements to this map are in development. This map is in beta, please provide any feedback via this form (external link) (external link) . --- Section Separator --- Personal and business travel across an Alert Level boundaries is strictly limited to essential movement. You may only travel between Alert Level areas if that travel is permitted. You also need to make sure you have acceptable evidence that you are permitted to cross the boundary. You can apply for an exemption if your reason to cross an Alert Level boundary is not permitted. You should stay home, unless it is essential to do otherwise. Personal travel permissions to cross an Alert Level boundary Business travel permissions to cross an Alert Level boundary Travelling into and out of Northland is a little more difficult while it shares a boundary with Auckland. Find out more about travelling into and out of Northland --- Section Separator --- Movement within Alert Level 4 area is limited, except for the permitted reasons. If you are leaving home for one of the permitted reasons, you do not require any other form of approval. You should carry some evidence of your reason to leave your home. Permitted movement within Alert Level 4 area --- Section Separator --- Waka Kotahi’s Journey Planner uses the latest travel time information, traffic cameras, and updates on delays, roadworks and road closures to help you plan your journey.
